concepts.heading: What it is
concepts.body: Distributed Storage covers the design decisions needed to build reliable systems and explain those decisions in interviews. The core focus is understanding Object storage, Chunking, Deduplication and linking each concept to an architecture consequence.

concepts.heading: Why it matters in interviews
concepts.body: Interviewers expect you to justify trade-offs, not just list tools. For Distributed Storage, strong answers connect constraints, architecture choices, and failure behavior while staying explicit about what you would de-scope first.

flowSteps: Clarify scope and constraints for Distributed Storage before choosing architecture primitives.
Define boundaries for Object storage and map request/write paths.
Introduce resilience points such as retries, idempotency, and observability checkpoints.
Evaluate bottlenecks under peak load or feature expansion assumptions.
Capture final trade-offs and explain why rejected alternatives were not selected.

tradeoffs.chooseWhen: Prefer option A for correctness-critical flows in Distributed Storage; choose option B for read-heavy workloads with tolerant staleness.
tradeoffs.risk: Choosing incorrectly can either over-complicate the stack or produce stale data under failures.

tradeoffs.optionA: Fast in-memory path with async persistence
tradeoffs.chooseWhen: Use fast path when user experience and throughput dominate; use durable path for financial or irreversible operations.
tradeoffs.risk: Async persistence increases loss window; sync persistence increases tail latency.

tradeoffs.chooseWhen: Adopt sharding when clear data volume growth exists; stay simple when traffic is modest and team size is small.
tradeoffs.risk: Premature sharding raises ops burden; delaying too long can cause painful migrations.

tradeoffs.chooseWhen: Choose multi-region for strict global SLA and low-latency demands; choose single region to control cost and complexity.
tradeoffs.risk: Multi-region introduces replication and consistency challenges; single-region increases outage blast radius.

examples.name: Cloud Drive
examples.context: Cloud Drive demands clear boundaries around Object storage and predictable behavior during peak usage.
examples.designChoice: Use a staged design with a fast path and a durable path, then expose explicit fallback behavior to callers.
examples.why: This keeps latency stable for normal traffic while preserving correctness for critical writes and failure recovery.

examples.name: Media Backup
examples.context: Media Backup introduces changing requirements and forces design updates without breaking existing clients.
examples.designChoice: Introduce stable interfaces, versioned contracts, and observability from the start so changes remain testable.
examples.why: You can iterate safely while preserving backward compatibility and maintaining confidence in production behavior.

cheatSheet: Start every Distributed Storage answer with assumptions and limits.
Name one latency-sensitive path and one correctness-sensitive path.
State how Object storage is written and read under load.
Explain one scaling strategy and one fallback strategy.
Mention observability: metrics, logs, and tracing checkpoints.
Call out a deliberate de-scope to keep MVP practical.
Finish with what you would improve in version two.
redFlags: Choosing technology without linking it to constraints.
Ignoring data consistency or idempotency for write operations.
No failure-mode story for dependency outages.
No plan to measure whether the design is actually working.
